results.title: The Phantom. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: B Reeves Eason, Rudolph C. Flothow and Columbia
results.brief_description: Episodes six to ten. Originally a comic-strip character written by Lee Falk and drawn by Ray Moore, This popular serial featured Tom Tyler as The Ghost Who Walks and Ace the Wonder Dog as Devil. Faithful to the original strip, in the first episode The Phantom is killed by the evil Dr. Bremmer and his equally evil henchmen. As the story continues, we see his son (Tyler) adopting his father’s costume and perpetuating the myth that The Phantom is back from the dead. Eventually scientists (evil) try to kill The Phantom for good so they can take the Lost City of Zoloz and replace The Phantom with an imposter to trick the natives into slavery. Will The Phantom survive? Will the natives succumb to evil? Cast includes: Kenneth R. MacDonald, Frank Shannon, Jeanne Bates, Guy Kingsford, Joe Devlin, Ernie Adams, John Bagni.

results.title: The Phantom. Vol. 1
results.creator_credit: B Reeves Eason, Rudolph C. Flothow and Columbia
results.brief_description: Volume one contains the first five episodes of the movie serial that first brought The Phantom to the large screen. Originally a comic-strip character written by Lee Falk and drawn by Ray Moore, This popular serial featured Tom Tyler as The Ghost Who Walks and Ace the Wonder Dog as Devil. Faithful to the original strip, in the first episode The Phantom is killed by the evil Dr. Bremmer and his equally evil henchmen. results.title: The Peter principle (TEFC)
results.brief_description: In any hierarchical organization, en employee tend to se to his level of incompetence and remains there. Dr Laurence J. Peters outlines the dangers of working in a hierarchy and offers advice to employers and employees on the best use of the Peter Principle. The serious social implications from both an individual and organisational viewpoint includes stress related illness, unbalanced home life, inefficiency and incompetence.

results.title: The Persistent seed
results.creator_credit: Christopher Chapman, Hugh O'Connor and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A film by Christopher Chapman, known for his lyrical films of countryside and wilderness. He turns his colour camera on the growing city and there finds cheering proof that despite concrete and bulldozer, the persistent seed prevails. The film is without commentary and the camera work is a constant delight, for Chapman has the gift of catching life smiling wherever he may look. Film without words.

results.title: The Performing bear
results.creator_credit: Lliam Amor and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: This hand-painted animation has no narration, but the story is simply and beautifully told through the use of images. It is the tale of a travelling circus, whose only performer is a brown bear, which is badly treated by it’s cruel master. Due to waning interest in the performance of the star act, the circus master closes the circus and sells the bear to three men who, unbeknownst to him, wish to set the bear free, only to hunt it down. The bear eludes his would-be killers, finds a deserted tricycle and escapes to freedom using his talents. The film provides a beautiful metaphor for the triumph of the human spirit under the weight of great oppression, if we rely on our wits and use our skills and talents to provide the strength and opportunity required to escape our bonds, anything is possible.

results.title: The Perfect moment
results.creator_credit: Greg MacGillivray and MacGillivray Freeman Films
results.brief_description: Focuses on various skilled athletes as they attain instances of total physical and mental control, when a combination of technique, opportunity, training, drive and environmental conditions product moments of perfection. With Jan-Michael Vincent and narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: The Perfect hero
results.creator_credit: Barbara Doran, Kent Martin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An insider’s look at the business of romantic fiction writing at Harlequin Publishing. Writers, editors, designers and the male models who pose for the book covers discuss their own roles and the expectations of the readers. Readers discuss the appeal of the romantic genre, and argue its literary merit. Features interviews with writers Barbara Cartland, Virginia Henley and Heather Graham.

results.title: The Perfect English village
results.creator_credit: Nigel Farrell, VATV and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: Producer/director/author and broadcaster Nigel Farrell leaves the chaos of the city in his Morris-Minor in search of the perfect, tranquil, village. Does it exist? Nigel is determined to find out. On his mission he locates beautiful villages in Sussex, Wiltshire, Devon, Essex and North Yorkshire, none of which seems to fit his impression of the perfect village. Nigel does eventually solve the puzzle of a tranquil idyll, but not where you expect it.
